children.name: mind
children.definition: what you use to think and imagine things: tâm trí
examples: His mind was full of big ideas for developing the company.
Dave struggled hard to push these worries out of his mind.try not to think about them
It is impossible to understand the complex nature ofthe human mind.
Mind and body are closely related.
Meditation involves focussing the mind on a single object or word.
independence/strength/flexibility of mind
men who were chosen for their independence of mind
in sb’s mind
There was no doubt in my mind that it was the right decision to make.
Do you have a clear picture in your mind of what you want?
A plan began to form in his mind.
The event is still fresh in most people’s minds.
at the back of your mindwhen an idea is not very clear or certain
At the back of my mind I had the funny feeling that I’d met her somewhere before.
your mind wanders youcannot make yourself concentrate on a particular subject , and you start thinking about other things
The teacher talked on and on and my mind began to wander.
what’s going on in sb’s mindwhat somebody is thinking
I never know what’s going on in her mind.
turn sth over in your mindthink about something carefully
It was an interesting idea. Jeff turned it over in his mind on the way to work. bbbb
go/run through your mind
The same thoughts kept going through my mind and I couldn’t get to sleep.

children.name: brain
children.definition: the ability to think clearly and learn quickly: trí tuệ, trí óc
examples: If you had any brains, you’d know what I meant.
The job requires brains.
My brain worked fast as I tried to decide what to do.
Branson has an excellent business brain.

children.name: have brains
examples: You should have more brains than to smoke.

children.name: use your brain
examples: It’s easy if you just use your brain.

children.name: rack your brains
children.definition: try very hard to think of something
examples: If we all rack our brains we should come up with some ideas.

children.name: pick sb’s brains
children.definition: ask someone for ideas
examples: I thought I’d pick Greg's brains about what to take with us.

children.name: it takes/requires brains to do sth
examples: It takes brains to think of a plan like that.

children.name: sth addles your brain
children.definition: makes you unable to think clearly
examples: The alcohol had addled his brain.

children.name: a good/quick brain
examples: It was obvious that Ann had a good brain.

children.name: head
children.definition: sb’s mind - use this especially when talking about the thoughts that are in sb’s mind: đầu
examples: Dan’s head was full of big ideas.
The problem only exists inside his head.
what’s going on in sb’s headwhat somebody is thinking
She’s so quiet - you never quite know what’s going on inside her head.
do sth in your head(= calculate something mentally )
I can’t do those figures in my head.
Use your headto work out the answer.
come into/pop into your head
Jackie said the first thing that came into her head.
get sth into your head(= understand something )
‘It’s over, Jake,’ she said. ‘Try and get that into your head.’
take/get it into your head (to do sth)(= decide to do something, especially something stupid )
At about two in the morning, Alan took it into his head to go for a swim.
get/put sth out of your head(= stop thinking or worrying about something )
Try to put it out of your head for the time being.
put sth into sb’s head(= make someone think or believe something )
What’s put that idea into her head?
get your head round sthBritish English(= be able to understand something )
I just can’t get my head round what’s been going on here.

children.name: subconscious
children.definition: the part of your mind that influences the way you think or behave, even though you may not realize this is happening, and which makes you have dreams: tiềm thức
examples: the subconscious
When you go to sleep it is only the conscious mind that shuts down. The subconscious cannot do so.
anger buried deep in the subconscious
During the daytime our conscious minds are active, but during the nightthe subconscioustakes over.
sb’s subconscious
She suddenly remembered a traumatic incident that had beenburied deep in her subconscious.
Our subconscious plays tricks with us sometimes and we may imagine that we are seeing thingssuch as ghosts.
subconscious[adj]
the subconscious mind
our subconscious desires

children.name: psyche
children.definition: sb’s mind, especially their feelings and attitudes, and the way these influence their character- used especially when talking about people's minds in general: tinh thần, linh hồn, tâm thần
examples: The need for love is deeply buried in our psyche.

children.name: the fragile psyche of a teenager
examples: The need for love is deeply buried in our psyche.

children.name: the human/female/American etc psychethe typical psyche of a human, female etc
examples: Freud has provided an account of the human psyche’s different stages of development.
Freud has provided an account ofthe human psyche's stages of development.
The child is simply searching his psyche to find some past event that relates to his new experiences.

children.name: a definite character that makes sb different from other people
identity
children.definition: the definite character that a person or group sees themselves as having, which lets them feel different and separate from everyone else:
examples: She was afraid marriage would cause her to lose her identity.
The islanders are proud of their strong regional identity.
Travelling alone can lead to aloss of identity.

children.name: sense of identitythe feeling that you have a strong identity
examples: Many teenagers play sports to gain a sense of identity.
Children need continuity, security, and asense of identity.

children.name: national/cultural/social etc identity(= a strong feeling of belonging to a particular group, race etc )
examples: Our strong sense of national identity has been shaped by our history.

children.name: identity crisis/crisis of identity(= a feeling of uncertainty about who you really are and what your purpose is )
examples: My father experienced an identity crisis in middle age.

children.name: individuality
children.definition: the quality of being clearly different from other people and having your own personal character: cá tính riêng biệt, con người riêng biệt
examples: It’s difficult to be part of a highly organized group such as the armed forces without losing some of your individuality.
We have a close working relationship while retaining our individuality and separate interests.

children.name: personality
children.definition: the quality of being interesting, friendly, and enjoyable to be with, that makes someone seem very different from most other people: cá tính
examples: Everyone loves her for her cheerful personality.
Yes, he’s got plenty of talent and ambition, but he’s got no personality.
Billie Holiday or Bessie Smith had more personality than a hundred of today’s pop singers.
He’s honest but he lacks personality.

children.name: mental
children.definition: trí óc, trí tuệ, tinh thần
examples: 1relating to the health or state of someone’s mind :
After months of overworking, Briggs was suffering from mental and physical exhaustion.
Stress has an effect on both your physical andmental health.
mentally[adv] B2 về mặt tinh thần
By the end of the day we were mentally and physically worn out.
I was exhausted, both physically and mentally.

children.name: mental illness/problem/breakdownan illness, problem etc of your mind, not your body
examples: Rick had a complete mental breakdown after his family died in a car crash.
The centre provides help for people suffering frommental illness.
2relating to the mind and thinking, or happening only in the mind :
It takes a lot of mental effort to understand these ideas.

children.name: a child’s mental development
examples: You need to develop a positivemental attitude.

children.name: mental picture/imagea picture that you have in your mind
examples: I’d never met Jane’s boyfriend, but I had a clear mental picture of what he looked like.
I tried to get a mental picture of him from her description.

children.name: psychological
children.definition: affecting the mind - use this especially about mentalproblemsthat influence the way sb behaves: tâm lí
examples: The cause of a physical illness can often be psychological.
a psychological problem
She works with children who have psychological problems.
psychologically[adv] B2
psychologically disturbed children

children.name: unconscious/subconscious feelings, desires, worries etc
children.definition: are hidden in your mind and you do not realize that you have them: tiềm thức
examples: People who come to me for counselling are very often suffering from unconscious feelings of guilt.
a subconscious fear of failure
unconscious feeling/desire/need etc
an unconscious need to be loved
my unconscious desirignorancee to impress him
subconsciouslyC2/ unconscious[adv] theo tiềm thức
Fathers are often subconsciously jealous of their sons.
Subconsciously, he blames himself for the accident.

children.name: character
children.definition: the combination of qualities that makes someone a particular kind of person, for example a good or bad, honest or dishonest person: tính cách, tính nết, cá tính
examples: Her behavior last night revealed a lot about her character.
A candidate’s character and qualifications are more important than past experience.
What strikes me most about Hamlet is his noble character.
He has a cheerful but quiet character.
Children grow up with a mixture ofcharacter traits(= character qualities )from both sides of their family.
his temper and othercharacter flaws(= bad qualities )
in character/out of character(= typical or untypical of sb’ character )
He swore, which was out of character for him.
It would be veryout ofcharacter of her to lie.
It's notin hischaracter to be jealous.
the English/French etc character
Openness is at the heart of the American character.
Politeness is traditionally part of the British character.
character sketch(= a description of sb’s character)

children.name: personality
children.definition: sb’s character - use this especially about how sb behaves towards other people, for example whether they are friendly or unfriendly, confident or easily frightened etc: nhân cách, tính tình
examples: It’s true he can be emotional at times but that’s just part of his personality.
This election should be about issues and policies, not about the personalities of the candidates!

children.name: a strong personality
examples: Mercer has a strong personality and always tells you his opinion.

children.name: a forceful personality
examples: The architect’s forceful personality ensured that the work progressed rapidly.

children.name: a dominant personality
children.definition: controlling other people
examples: He had a dominant personality and could be a bit of a bully.

children.name: a warm personality
children.definition: friendly and kind to people
examples: Everyone who knew Roseanne will miss her warm personality.

children.name: an outgoing/extrovert personality
children.definition: liking to talk to people
examples: The job requires someone with an outgoing personality.

children.name: an engaging personality
children.definition: pleasant, so that people like you
examples: He is strikingly handsome with a very engaging personality.

children.name: a bubbly personality
children.definition: happy and eager to do things
examples: Her bright and bubbly personality made her one of the most popular girls in her year.

children.name: a lively/vivacious personality
children.definition: liking to meet and talk to people
examples: Her lively personality won her many admirers.

children.name: a charismatic personality
children.definition: strong and attractive, so that people admire and respect you
examples: Like many other people, I was attracted by his charismatic personality.

children.name: a personality traitformal
children.definition: a part of your personality
examples: She shares many of her mother’s personality traits.

children.name: a personality disorder
children.definition: a mental illness affecting someone’s personality
examples: The hospital treats patients with severe personality disorders.

children.name: a personality clash
children.definition: when people cannot work together because they are so different
examples: The band eventually split because of personality clashes.

children.name: a personality test
examples: Employers are increasingly using personality tests to help them select staff.

children.name: friendly/ nice/ warm etc personality
examples: Yun has a lovely, warm personality.
Despite their different personalities, they became the best of friends.

children.name: in personality
examples: Unfortunately, the illness can lead to changes in personality.

children.name: nature
children.definition: sb’s character - use this especially to say whether someone is naturally good or bad, gentle or severe etc: bản chất , bản tính
examples: ▪ Kindness and sympathy were in his nature.
▪ My girlfriend has a rather unforgiving nature so I don’t think that I’ll tell her.
▪ She was surprised to learn he had a romantic side to his nature.

children.name: by natureuse this when saying what someone’s usual character is
examples: She’s generous by nature.
I am not by nature a violent man, but these insults were more than I could bear.
He isbynature inclined to be rather lazy.

children.name: it’s not in sb’s nature to do sth
examples: It was not in his nature to take risks.
It's not reallyinher naturetobe aggressive.

children.name: temperament
children.definition: the emotional part of sb’s character, especially how likely they are to become angry, happy, sad etc: tính khí
examples: His calm, quiet temperament made him popular with his colleagues.
My father and I got along very well, having very similar temperaments.

children.name: the right temperament
examples: I’m not sure if she has the right temperament for the job.

children.name: artistic/nervous/good etc temperament
examples: Jill has such a lovely relaxed temperament.

children.name: by temperament
examples: Tolkien was, by temperament, a very different man from Lewis.

children.name: make-up
children.definition: British /makeupAmerican  sb’s character - use this especially to say that sb’s character is completelyfixedand theycannotchangeit or control it: tính cách (vững)
examples: ▪ It’s not in their make-up to accept defeat.
▪ Her constant attempts to justify her actions tell the reader a lot about her emotional make-up.
▪ This behaviour is part of our genetic make-up rather than our cultural conditioning.
Pride has always been an important part of his make-up.
sb’s genetic/psychological make-up
a possible link between genetic make-up and criminal behaviour
be part of sb’s make-up
Stubbornness has always been a significant part of his makeup

children.name: what makes sb tick
children.definition: if you know what makes sb tick, you understand their character, desires, and what makes them behave in the way they do:
examples: ▪ After working with him for five years, I still don’t know what makes him tick.
▪ As a teacher, you need to get to know your students, find out what makes them tick.

children.name: disposition
children.definition: a nervous/jealous etc  formal a character that makes it likely that you will behave nervously, jealously etc: “thiên hướng”, tính tình; tâm tính; tính khí
examples: This program may not be suitable for people with a nervous disposition.

children.name: be of a nervous/jealous etc disposition
examples: He’s considerate and sweet-tempered but of a very nervous disposition.
Sheis ofa nervous/cheerful/sunny disposition.

children.name: have a nervous/jealous etc disposition
examples: Sue had a sunny disposition and a warm smile.

children.name: true colours
children.definition: UK /truecolorsUS  if sb shows their true colours they do something that shows what they are really like, when they have been pretending to be something different: bản chất thật, con người thật
examples: With the elections safely behind him, Hitler began to show his true colours.
He was friendly to me at first but he showed his true colors when we were both up for the same promotion.

children.name: underneath
children.definition: if sb is nice, jealous, frightened etc underneath, they really are nice, jealous, or frightened even though their behaviour shows a different gy character: dưới vẻ bề ngoài

children.name: I know that she seems very aggressive, but underneath she’s really quite shy
examples: Underneath all that boastful talk you’ll find that he’s actually a very nice guy.

children.name: underneath it all
examples: She laughed as if she was joking but underneath it all, I knew she meant it.

children.name: deep down
children.definition: if sb is cruel, dishonest, good etc deep down, that is their true character even though they hide this in their usual behaviour: trong thâm tâm, sâu bên trong
examples: Deep down, I think she’s really very ambitious.
Yeah, sometimes he can be really nice and polite but, I tell you, deep down he’s an animal!

children.name: at heart
children.definition: if you are a particular type of person at heart, that is your true character even though you may sometimes think you are different: thực chất
examples: She’s a traveller at heart. You’ll never get her to settle down.
Paul was an easy-going fellow at heart who wanted only to enjoy himself.

children.name: quality
children.definition: sth such as an ability or a way of behaving that is part of sb’s character:
examples: phẩm chất
Besides intelligence and charm, Bella had some less desirable qualities.
The essential quality of a good parent is patience.
Among his other endearing qualities, Ralph was an exceedingly patient man.
He shows strongleadership qualities.
He has a lot of good qualities but being organized isn't one of them.
thepersonal qualitiesnecessary to be a successful salesman
quality of
the qualities of honesty and independence
[ + to infi ]I don't think he has the right qualitiestobe a teacher.

children.name: attribute
children.definition: a part of someone’s character, especially a part that is thought by other people to be good and useful: đặc tính,
examples: The attribute that people found most attractive in Sharon was her optimism.
Hope is one of mankind’s most enduring and rewarding attributes.
He had all the attributes of a great leader: charisma, energy, discipline, and resourcefulness.
What attributes should a good manager possess?

children.name: characteristic
children.definition: sb’s characteristics are the qualities that are typical of them and which make them easy to recognize: đặc trưng
examples: All great leaders share certain characteristics which must be seen as the key to their success.
Ralph can be very mean sometimes. It’s one of his less endearing characteristics.

children.name: trait
children.definition: one type of feeling or behaviour that is particularly noticeable in a person or group of people: đặc điểm, nét tiêu biểu
examples: It’s a human trait to joke about subjects that make us uncomfortable
His sense of humour is one of his better traits.
personality/character traits
a mental illness associated with particular personality traits
Certain personality traits make people more likely to become victims of violent crime.
Arrogance is a very unattractivepersonality/charactertrait.
genetic/inherited traits
family traita trait shared by members of a family
Pride seems to be one of our family traits.

children.name: romantic/serious/funny etc side
children.definition: a part of sb’s character, especially one that is very different from the rest of their character: phần con người
examples: Canning was a very traditional Englishman but he had a surprisingly romantic side to him as well.
Val revealed her wild side at the office party.
After his arrest people realized that there had always been a darker side to his nature.
She seems quite fierce, but actually she has a gentle side.

children.name: part
children.definition: one part of someone’s character, which makes them behave or feel in particular ways:

children.name: part of sb
examples: Part of me loves going to parties but there’s another part that prefers staying at home.
There is a part of her that I just don’t understand.

children.name: streak
children.definition: a part of someone’s character that is quite different from the rest of their character, especially one that makes them behave badly: nét

children.name: mean/nasty/ violent etc streak
examples: She had a mean streak that she didn’t bother to hide.

children.name: The District Attorney argued that Johnson has a violent streak and is a danger to society
thing
children.definition: a part of someone’s character, especially one that you like or dislike: điểm

children.name: One of the things I like about Susan is the way she always keeps smiling, even when there are problems
examples: The nicest thing about Richard is that he doesn’t mind being criticized.

children.name: point
children.definition: điểm
examples: good/ bad/strong et pointsgood or bad things about sb’s character:
Fred was a bad manager but he had his good points.

children.name: She always tried to be fair with her students and not just stress their bad points
examples: When you’re dead people don’t remember your faults -- only your good points.
He's boring, but I suppose he has his good points.
I think her kindness is one of her strong points (= one of her good qualities) .

children.name: quirk
children.definition: a strange or unusual habit or part of sb’s character: tật xấu

children.name: Although on the outside he was quiet and shy, Albert had more than his share of quirks
examples: She took pride in her children’s quirks and individuality, and made no effort to try to change them.

children.name: there’s sth about sb U
children.definition: there’s sth about sbyou say this when there is sth about a person’s character that you like or dislike, but you’re not sure exactly what it is:
examples: I don’t know what it is, but there’s something about that man which really irritates me.

children.name: heart
children.definition: nounEMOTIONS trái tim

children.name: characteristic
children.definition: a quality or feature of something or someone that is typical of them and easy to recognize
examples: characteristic of
a baby discovering the physical characteristics of objects
defining/distinguishing characteristic(= one that separates someone or something from others of the same type )
Violent images are a defining characteristic of his work.
a physical characteristicphysical characteristics such as your height and weight

children.name: a personal characteristic
children.definition: relating to someone’s character
examples: What are the personal characteristics that a leader requires?

children.name: a human characteristic
examples: The power of speech is an entirely human characteristic.

children.name: a national characteristic
children.definition: typical of the people of a country
examples: Organization is often seen as a German national characteristic.

children.name: the main characteristic of something
examples: A new interest in art was one of the main characteristics of this period.

children.name: a common characteristic
children.definition: that people or things share
examples: Successful firms tend to have common characteristics.

children.name: a distinguishing/distinctive characteristic
children.definition: separating someone or something from others of the same type
examples: The blue feathers are the distinguishing characteristic of the male bird.

children.name: a defining characteristic
children.definition: one that is necessary in order to be a particular type of person or thing
examples: Originality is one of the defining characteristics of a great band.

children.name: an important/essential characteristic
examples: An essential characteristic of good teaching is that it must create interest in the learner.

children.name: an inherited characteristic
examples: Intelligence is an inherited characteristic.

children.name: a striking characteristic
examples: Its canals are one of Amsterdam’s most striking characteristics.

children.name: have a characteristic
children.definition: alsopossess a characteristicformal
examples: He has all the characteristics of a great husband.

children.name: show a characteristic
children.definition: alsoexhibit a characteristicformal
examples: A material may exhibit the characteristics of both a liquid and a solid.

children.name: share a characteristic
examples: The group shared one characteristic - they were all under 25.

children.name: inherit a characteristic
children.definition: get a characterstic from your parent
examples: We all inherit physical characteristics from our parents.

children.name: mentality
children.definition: an attitude that a particular group of people has, which makes them behave in a way,especially one that you think is wrong or bad: trạng thái tâm lý, tâm tính
examples: I don’t understand the mentality of these teenagers.
She despised the bourgeois mentality of the professional class.
You know, I wonder if this is a male kind of mentality.
I just don't understand the mentality of these people.
They all seem to have a kind of victim mentality, which makes them think that the world is permanently against them.

children.name: spirit
children.definition: nounNOT BODY tâm hồn

children.name: ego
children.definition: the opinion that you have about yourself: cái tôi

children.name: big/enormous etc ego
examples: Richard has the biggest ego(= thinks he is very clever and important )of anyone I’ve ever met.
That promotion reallyboostedherego(= made her feel better about herself ).
I need someone to massage mybruised ego(= when you feel less confident than before ).

children.name: ego
children.definition: bản ngã
examples: the egotechnicalthe part of your mind that gives you your sense of who you are - used especially in Freudian psychology :

children.name: the rational world of the ego and the irrational world of the unconscious
identity
children.definition: sb’s identity is their name or who they are:
examples: The identity ofthe killer is still unknown.
sb’s real/true identityThe true identity of the author was not revealed until 100 years later.
a new/different identityHe avoided arrest by adopting a new identity.
a false identity(= when someone pretends to be another person )He used a fake passport to assume a false identity.

children.name: find out/discover sb’s identity
examples: The police have yet to discover the victim’s identity.

children.name: know sb’s identity
examples: He wanted to know the identity of his real father.

children.name: hide/conceal sb’s identity
examples: She used a false name to conceal her identity.

children.name: reveal/disclose sb’s identity
children.definition: show or say who a person is
examples: The company did not reveal the identity of the prospective buyer.

children.name: give away sb’s identity
children.definition: accidentally reveal it
examples: The thief gave away his identity by mistake.

children.name: protect sb’s identity
children.definition: make sure no one finds out who someone is
examples: Journalists frequently protect the identity of confidential sources.

children.name: adopt/assume an identity
children.definition: give yourself a new identity
examples: She assumed a false identity and went to live in South America.

children.name: identity card/papers/documents
children.definition: documents that show who you are
examples: Each member of staff is issued with an identity card.

children.name: an identity paradeBritish English
children.definition: when someone looks at a line of people to see if they recognize a criminal
examples: The victim identified her attacker from an identity parade.

children.name: identity theft/fraud
children.definition: the crime of stealing another person's personal details in order to pretend to be that person
examples: Identity theft is becoming more and more common because of the Internet.

children.name: proof of identity
children.definition: something that proves you are who you say you are
examples: You’ll need proof of identity, such as a driving licence.

children.name: a case of mistaken identity
children.definition: when people think that someone is a different person, especially with the result that they are accused of something that they did not do
examples: The defendant claimed he’d been arrested in a case of mistaken identity.
